blocks.text: Example 2.— In a chain survey four measurements of a base line $ 867.35, 867.41, 867.62$ and $ 867.43$ are taken. Find the best length and the probable error.
The best result is the A.M. of these.

blocks.description: The arithmetic mean (A.M.) of the four measurements.

blocks.text: The total links $ 867.41 $ yields a probable error.

blocks.description: Calculating the probable error based on the number of observations.

blocks.text:
675.5  \pm  0.6265 =  674.875  

so that the base line measurement $ 867.41 $ is subject to an error of 0.157 inch, and this result could not be bettered it would be derived from the existing | data, (Cf. ‘repetition,’ when working with the mean).
